comments.commentBody: War and/or famine has taken car of excess population in the past, and will in the future, but let's resist the temptation to intervene in others behalf.

So let me get this straight... these poor Muslim women are being discriminated against because they aren't allowed to wear veils at various public locations in France, such as schools, amusement parks, etc... Oh, the humanity!!!

However, the fact that in Muslim dominated countries they would be subject to torture, stonings, beheadings, arranged marriages, sexual mutilations, and a host of other atrocities doesn't compare to this "thinly veiled" issue of liberal bias.
Discrimination? Only if non-mudslim women ARE allowed to wear them.
John - not a liberl/conservative issue

How about reporting Christian native french women banned of wearing cross in public by secular govt in France?. Oh yes, they are Christians and it is okay to be discriminated. This discrimination by the liberals is  very disappointing.
the headscarf is a symbol of oppression.  I have a funny feeling a lot of countries will outlaw it. This is why western countries don't like it.  I can't stand it.

veil is the freedom not the other way around; it is to conceal from hungry men and feel free..off course I do not favor it but respected it and it is also used in other cultures such as slavic etc (half of russian women wear it

I always judge a religious or cultural norms by observing if it takes away or grants greater human freedoms. Looking at the veil, its intended to cover up and make a woman invisible from society and men, and therefore its taking away freedom from females. If the men had a wear a veil, I'd be more understanding of Islam but like hundreds who have posted comments here, I look at the veil as tool of female oppression and subjugation.

I stand by France government and not the Muslim population who wants to take away French freedoms and make their country more oppressive. Like many here I also question why they left their societies where they could practice their religion without progressive Western values judging their oppression of their women.
thank you...
Sounds like the way to see Maine.  All you're missing is some of those longnecks steamed.

The greater the pool of unemployment, the lower the costs of labor. This goes for skilled and white collar labor as much as tomato pickers and supermarket clerks.
The lower the costs of labor, the greater the profits of the big employers and the bigger the income of their corporate officers.
The bigger the profits of the big employers, the more demand for their stock and the higher the value of that stock.
The higher the value of the stock, the more demand for it in big mutual funds to ensure continuous growth.
The greater the continuous growth rate of the mutual funds the greater the demand for them by the people who have come to realize that they aren't going to get anywhere from their wages and/or salaries, which are being kept low by the pool of unemployed.

This is a classic ratatouille, and super easy to make. Just do all the chopping in advance, and it's a breeze. I served it with a combo of rice -- brown, red, and wild. Delicious.

My husband, who claims not to like eggplant, gobbled it up.
I just started the puzzle and filled in VAN GOGH.  Nice synchronicity as we are just about to dock in Arles.

I could not agree more. There are minerals everywhere. The question is are they concentrated enough to be economically exploited. No mention of China's copper project? What is the status of that? People no longer look upon a job in a mining or metallurgical operation as way out of poverty, just a type of indentured servitude.

The reported new found rich mineral deposits worth trillions of dollars provide yet another long sought an excuse to delay US presence in Afghanistan beyond the declared withdrawal date,  of course,  this time on the pretext of development and not to fight Taliban whom the US now wants to befriend with through dubious deals with the help of many friendly and not so  friendly nations and non-state actors.
Also delicious with olive oil, a lot of garlic, and salt, pepper and regiano cheese.

Super easy and very fast to make with just a vegetable peeler. Best use for those large bags of zucchini on sale! Delicious, even without the sauce.

I didn't discard the zucchini core, but chopped it up and put it in the ratatouille I made the following day.

As much as Marx is out of  favor, his basic observations and analyses still stand up. Such as, that capitalism would be the great engine that powered the productivity of industry to new heights, but once we were past the stage of supplying the masses with the basic needs of life, it would not be able to dispense the rewards of said productivity in a manner which correlates with the responsibility for it.

Lee -

I think we have rough agreement here. Perhaps you should consider using your skills to make and implement the improvements in small diesel engines which you favor.

BTW, I never said large, centralized distribution was "the recipe". That was yet another straw man brought up by someone else. Ref. my ideas doing nothing - I would strongly favor improvements to fresh water access and separation of waste from drinking water. Small, local and efficient sources of electrical power would be tremendous as well - from whatever source (fossil, or otherwise). And coal certainly will play a major role going forward in China and India.

Kurt in Switzerland

By not recognizing blacks as human -- that was the strategy then, and is still the strategy of people like Rand Paul who, if memory serves, has written that he believes that business people should be able to determine for themselves whom to serve in their public accomodations.  Civil libertarians believe that all people should be recognized as equal before the law, and that the the rule of law is required to maintain that recognition.  Rand Paul is not a Libertarian, only a Republican riding on his Republican/Libertarian father's coattails.

The Republicans made the decision a few decades back to harness the power of craziness, which the Democrats were reluctant to get involved with. That turned out to be wildly successful, as the strain of craziness in America runs deeper than I (for one) would have predicted. But like riding the tiger, riding those disadvantaged in the field of cognitive skills proves a practice which is dangerous to discontinue.

Crepes, wonderful crepes!
My mother called them 'big pancakes' and probably fried 25 or so one after the other for my four siblings and myself for breakfast. All we put on them was butter and cinnamon sugar.
When I began making them myself, I realized like so many old world recipes, the ingredients were simple, and the technique needed to be learned. The pan must be very hot. You add the butter in the center and let it bubble and sizzle, then pour in the batter into the center of the butter and lift and tilt the pan around to enlarge the batter into a circle. But not too perfect--the irregular 'fingers' that stream off and get extra crispy make a crepe wonderful. And if the butter sizzles properly, you get a crepe that has a lot of little browned bubble spots.
I now make them for my family. Our preferred treatment is french butter (beurre d'isigny with coarse salt), meyer lemon juice and powdered sugar. Sublime.

.
Martin, it's bad enough that Factboy abandoned us when we needed his guidance on Academy Award categories; but what was the point of you learning how to think like John if you never use your powers?

I'm talking about some guesswork as to who John may have selected as an avatar, and why.

Fine, I'll try. But since I don't think like John, I'm making 3 guesses:

1. Darlene LOVE. Heavily featured in a film that won an Oscar for BEST Documentary ("20 feet from stardom"). Broadcast on (recent avatar) David Letterman's shows, singing the same song, from 1986 through 2014. Probably recorded with, or for, some group from Chicago. May have written, or sung background on, some song played on "Mad Men".

2. Andre Agassi. Undisputed BEST player in the world for some time. Cleveland connection via James Brown (read anecdote in Wiki Agassi article). (John's firm was Cleveland-based.) XWP-friendly last name. Well known for his LOVE MATCH with ...

3. Steffi Graf. Winner of many LOVE GAMES. Father well-known for frequent court appearances (that's criminal court, not tennis court). Also was the undisputed BEST in the world for some time. Most important, one of her crazed German fans stabbed Monica Seles (then ranked No. 1) so Graf could regain No. 1 standing (which she did). Bringing a knife to a tennis fight? "That's the Chicago way." Bonus: Highly photogenic.

All 3 meet the Tuesday criteria, I believe.

Only a few plying in Europe or Japan would be making more than a subsistence wage in the NWSL without the living subsidies that the USSF is paying to players who are making the roster. It's why the same players get run out, over and over again, even in meaningless friendlies. In a better world, those friendlies would be used to see up and coming prospects, but without making a minimum number of appearances, subsidies are cut, which is consequential. But it is not a system that is sustainable in the long run, nor is it for the ultimate betterment of the USWNT.
Re Scholarships: The most consequential misunderstanding about them is that, on the part of the schools and coaches, it is NOT a four year commitment; it is four, one year scholarships, renewable at the caprice of the coach. Tear a ligament, and the scholarship could be rescinded. Don't get along with the coach, and risk losing the ride. Have another recruit coming in who plays your position? You might not have a scholarship anymore.
It's cool that she recognizes that youth sports are pushing young children a little too hard and too soon.
With America having veto power, you still want  to talk about "UN".

Well, indicting corrupt FIFA officials wasn't on my list of "things I hope Obama does in his final months in office", but sure, why not?  It's long overdue and it's not like the UN or anyone else has the ability, jurisdiction and political will to do so.
